text.p: These are the leading stories in the Beirut press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-The conspiracy on state security is reduced to charging a Lebanese journalist with having contacts with Israel and distributing leaflets that incite military disobedience.
-Syrian Vice-President Khaddam: "We are awaiting a commitment from the United States to the guarantees it gave us on the issue of an Israeli pullout to the June 4, 1967 borders".
-Authorities are interrogating four suspects in the case of the attack on a bus carrying Syrian passengers in Tabaraja earlier this month.
-The Beirut Stock Exchange delists 38 companies that have not met listing requirements by December 21.
-Parliament Speaker Berri says Egyptian President Mubarak has informed him of his refusal to deploy Arab forces in south Lebanon.
-General Lahd, the commander of Israel's client South Lebanon Army militia, is in France on a long vacation.
-The ministry for displaced people says that 40 percent of the hundreds of thousands of war displaced have already returned to their original homes.
-Sheikh Fadlallah, the spiritual leader of Lebanon's pro-Iranian Shi'ite Moslem fundamentalists, says that the United States is pressuring Lebanon and Syria.
